section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children through dramatic play, and introduce vocabulary (stew, delicious).
Begin Story Time by introducing the big book and asking, Why did so many people knock on Omu’s door?
Read while noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Join related sentences.
Understand and use a growing number of theme words.
Show motivation to communicate; Share observations about events.
Take another perspective.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Economics:Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community; Show understanding that people have basic needs, e.g., food, clothing, and shelter.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show interest and appreciation for others’ work.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to identify the different ways people can share.
Encourage children to respond in complete sentences.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What types of buildings are in our community?
What can you pretend to cook?
Can you sort those blocks into blocks with letters and blocks with numbers?
What pictures of people in your community could you draw?
Draw your favorite food.
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word helpers? Can you write it?
Can you build a tall building out of blocks? How many floors will your building have?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Conversation; Listening; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder take another perspective and introduce vocabulary (give, together).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Thank You, Omu!
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Use regular and irregular past tense.
Understand and use a growing number of theme words.
Show motivation to communicate; Share observations about events.
Take another perspective.
Talk about roles and jobs of people in their community.
Show interest and appreciation for others’ work.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children talk about how Omu gave food to her neighbors and then they gave food to her.
Help children learn about taking different perspectives.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find a book that shows a place that looks like our community?
Pretend you just walked in the kitchen and smelled something delicious.
How would you build a building out of five blocks?
Can you draw someone who works in your community?
Can you draw a fire truck and color it red?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word give? Can you say what letter makes that sound?
Can you build a hospital? What materials will you use?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Make an Inference and introduce vocabulary (stirred, exclaimed).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Thank You, Omu! and asking the guiding question, Who are some of the people in Omu’s community?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Understand and use a growing number of theme words.
Show motivation to communicate; Share observations about events.
Take another perspective.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children act out different scenes from Thank You, Omu!
Encourage children to use their bodies and their voices to convey feelings, such as sadness, surprise, and anger.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are the homes in your books the same? How are they different?
Can you show me two things Omu was doing in the book?
Can you compare the size of two buildings? Which one is taller? How do you know?
Can you draw or write about a store you would like to work in?
How many different foods did Omu’s neighbors give her? Can you draw and color one of the foods?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word delicious?
Can you build a bus for people in your community? Who will be in the bus? How can you build a bus and people in the bus?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Thank You, Omu! by Oge Mora. Copyright © 2018 by Oge Mora. Cover copyright © 2018 by Hachette Book Group, Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Little, Brown and Company, a division of Hachette Book Group, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Super Jobs

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about community helpers and introduce vocabulary (doctor, firefighter).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Super Job s and Thank You, Omu!
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, Who are people who help in our community?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Understand and use a growing number of theme words.
Show motivation to communicate; Share observations about events.
Take another perspective.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community; Show understanding that people have basic needs, e.g., food, clothing, and shelter.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify places where different people in the community work.
Encourage children to talk about the different jobs they learn about.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How do you think the people in that story are feeling? Why do you think that?
Pretend you are a bus driver driving a school bus.
Pretend you are making a pizza. What toppings will you add?
What does a doctor do? Can you write about it?
Can you draw a picture of some of the things a firefighter uses for their job?
Can you show me what letter makes the beginning sound you hear in the word firefighter?
Can you build the tallest building in our community out of blocks? What will it be? Do people live or work in the building?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Thank You, Omu! by Oge Mora. Copyright © 2018 by Oge Mora. Cover copyright © 2018 by Hachette Book Group, Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Little, Brown and Company, a division of Hachette Book Group, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out scenes from Thank You, Omu! and to introduce vocabulary words (entered, celebrated).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, Why did Omu and her neighbors share their food with each other?
Read and retell interactively for engagement and imagination.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use a growing number of theme words.
Join related sentences.
Show motivation to communicate; Share observations about events.
Take another perspective.
Verbally share the meaning of own writing.
Talk about roles and jobs of the people in their community.
Act out to recreate or retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Who are the helpers in our school community? What do they do?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote your own book about our community, what would you put in it?
Pretend to share your food with a friend.
Can you work together to think of three ingredients to put in a stew?
Can you tell a story about Omu going to the supermarket?
Can you imagine a bakery with all of your favorite cakes and cookies and pies? What will you see? What will it smell like? Who will work there?
Imagine your favorite job. What letter does the first sound make?
Why did you use those materials to create your building? What do you like about them?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Are able to use language for different purposes.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Combine sentences that give lots of detail, stick to the topic, and clearly communicates intended meaning.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from her own.
Discuss the role and responsibilities of family, social, and community helpers
Demonstrate that all people need food, clothing, and shelter.
Demonstrate interest in and show appreciation for the creative work of others.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Are able to use language for different purposes.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from her own.
Discuss the role and responsibilities of family, social, and community helpers.
Demonstrate interest in and show appreciation for the creative work of others.

Are able to use language for different purposes.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from her own.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Discuss the role and responsibilities of family, social, and community helpers.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.

Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Discuss the role and responsibilities of family, social, and community helpers.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Are able to use language for different purposes.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Combine sentences that give lots of detail, stick to the topic, and clearly communicate intended meaning.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from her own.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Discuss the role and responsibilities of family, social, and community helpers.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
